title: Deontay Wilder makes Daniel Dubois prediction and slaps down Oleksandr Usyk
text:
The Bronze Bomber believes Dubois could even challenge him if he’s still fighting (Picture: Getty)

Deontay Wilder has picked out Daniel Dubois as the stand-out up-and-coming heavyweight boxer, while he says Oleksandr Usyk is ‘too small’ to pose a serious threat to him.

The Bronze Bomber puts his WBC belt on the line in November in a rematch with Luis Ortiz before taking on lineal champ Tyson Fury in February 2020 in what promises to be a mouth-watering battle.

After that, Wilder hopes to unify the division by taking on the winner of Anthony Joshua’s rematch with Andy Ruiz Jr, with the pair facing off again in Saudi Arabia in December.

Dubois has won four fights in 2019 already, all by knockout (Picture: Getty)

There are a host of established heavyweights lighting up the division currently, but Wilder says the emergence of 22-year-old Dubois – who stopped Ebenezer Tetteh in just two minutes last month – has not gone unnoticed.

Asked who has impressed him, Wilder told Sky Sports: ‘UK fighters definitely have some great guys on the horizon, I really like Daniel Dubois.

‘I’m really liking that kid, he’s strong, he seems very focused, he seems very disciplined in what he’s doing, he seems like he’s on a mission.

‘So I definitely wish him well in his pursuit of coming up. I think he’s going to be a good challenger.

‘Whether it’s me, and I’m still here, or whether it’s somebody else, I think he’s going to be a good challenger. I think he’s definitely going to make it to fight for a world title one day.

‘To be a champion? Who knows? But I think he’ll get to that point. I like a lot of the other guys as well, but for me he stands out the most.’

Wilder has written off Usyk’s chances of being a threat in the heavyweight division (Picture: Getty)

Usyk, meanwhile, will make his long-awaited step up from cruiserweight to heavyweight when he takes on Tyrone Spong later this month, though Wilder has written off the talented Ukrainian’s chances of ever beating him.

Wilder added: ‘Oleksandr Usyk is not a threat to me. He’s too small for me. He does a lot of movement and stuff like that, but that don’t phase me.’
